This afternoon, I spoke on the House floor in support of my amendment to rein in FISA and protect Americans‚Äô privacy, and I noted the hypocrisy of Republican and Democratic leaders on this issue. Here‚Äôs a short clip:  https://www.c-span.org/video/?c4803395/rep-amashs-closing-remarks-fisa-amendment¬†‚Ä¶
Thank you, @ACLU, for supporting the Amash-Lofgren amendment to stop the government from using FISA to violate Americans‚Äô civil liberties. pic.twitter.com/diey8vMGsM

Dozens of organizations from across the political spectrum, including @ACLU @FreedomWorks @DemandProgress @EFF and @IndivisibleTeam, support the Amash-Lofgren amendment to #HR2740 to limit the warrantless collection of Americans‚Äô data under FISA 702. pic.twitter.com/NMcgUO5bI2

Republicans, this is your chance to rein in the surveillance state.

Democrats, this is your chance to keep the president in check.

Vote YES on Amash-Lofgren. https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1140762333662367745¬†‚Ä¶

Our amendment upholds the Fourth Amendment by prohibiting the government from doing certain types of warrantless collections under FISA that unconstitutionally sweep up the private communications of countless law-abiding Americans. pic.twitter.com/NNBTP0eS83

FISA 702 allows the government to warrantlessly collect a massive amount of data. In doing so, it collects communications of Americans, which can be searched without a warrant and used in criminal prosecutions. This violates Americans‚Äô Fourth Amendment-secured rights.
AS SOON AS TUESDAY EVENING, the House will be voting on the Amash-Lofgren amendment to limit the warrantless collection of Americans‚Äô communications (including content) under Sec. 702 of FISA.

If the administration is serious about FISA abuse, then they‚Äôll support my amendment to rein in FISA‚Äîto better ensure that the government protects the privacy of all Americans in accordance with the Constitution.

Because the White House prevented us from fixing these issues last year, this week I‚Äôm offering an amendment to #HR2740 to narrow the government‚Äôs collections under FISA, limiting the warrantless gathering of Americans‚Äô communications.

The 2018 bill reauthorized Sec. 702 of FISA for six years‚Äîa section that allows for the warrantless collection of Americans‚Äô communications. In his statement after signing the bill, Pres. Trump‚Äôs only criticism was that he‚Äôd prefer that the bill reauthorize Sec. 702 permanently.

In 2018, we voted on FISA 702, and I offered an amendment to limit warrantless collection of Americans‚Äô communications. Instead of supporting that amendment, the White House issued a veto threat, and Trump ultimately signed a FISA 702 bill that creates even more privacy problems.

The Trump administration‚Äôs narrative allows the White House to complain about FISA abuse while at the same time fighting those of us in Congress who are actually trying to change the laws to prevent unconstitutional spying on Americans.

The White House is undermining this effort to fight unconstitutional surveillance by instead framing surveillance concerns as a problem with particular individuals at the FBI, as if protecting Americans‚Äô rights is just about hiring the right personnel, instead of changing FISA.

The reason for this focus is obvious: We can‚Äôt guarantee the government will always hire employees who will respect the people‚Äôs rights, so we have to ensure that the law prevents whoever is in government from violating the Constitution or acting without sufficient oversight.

Our primary concern has never been about particular individuals in government who use surveillance authorities; our focus is on limiting the authorities and adding safeguards so that Americans‚Äô rights are protected *regardless* of who in government is doing the surveillance.

Since before the Trump administration, I‚Äôve been leading a bipartisan coalition in Congress fighting the government‚Äôs efforts to expand the ability of agencies like the FBI and NSA to collect Americans‚Äô communications without a warrant.

This is part of a long-running effort to reform FISA and the Patriot Act‚Äîan effort that is being undermined by the Trump administration. Later this year, we‚Äôll have an opportunity to challenge Sec. 215 of the Patriot Act.

Last year, President Trump signed into law a bill to give the FBI and NSA extraordinary powers to warrantlessly collect Americans‚Äô communications under Sec. 702 of FISA. This week, the House will consider my amendment to #HR2740, offered with @RepZoeLofgren, to rein in FISA.

Happy Father‚Äôs Day to every great dad! I‚Äôm especially grateful for my amazing father, who was blessed to come to America as a refugee, and I‚Äôm missing my wonderful friend Walter Jones, who was like a father to me in Congress. Being a dad is the greatest joy of my life.

https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1138581732637237250?s=21¬†‚Ä¶

Unlike a contempt resolution, #HRes430 does not hold anyone in contempt of Congress. It allows for lawsuits to enforce subpoenas. Civil contempt of court is a possible outcome from this process, but this resolution does not in itself produce that outcome.

Here are two issues I tweeted about on Tuesday. In each case, I defend our Constitution, the Rule of Law, and the orderly working of our American institutions‚Äîand, in each case, the partisan reactions were perfectly predictable. The two-party system is hurting America.  https://twitter.com/reason/status/1138562802694516736¬†‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/EbnL9LHax6
Yes, but not a civil contempt resolution.

1. No such thing as a ‚Äúcivil‚Äù contempt resolution.
2. Criminal prosecution for contempt of Congress requires actual contempt vote.
3. Unlike contempt, today‚Äôs res authorizes lawsuits.
4. Terminology of members of Congress shouldn‚Äôt be emulated; both sides have incentive to hype.

Likely an honest mistake on @kyledcheney‚Äôs part, but since I‚Äôm getting a lot of questions about it, you should know that his description of the vote is inaccurate. It was not a vote to hold anyone in contempt. Here‚Äôs what it actually does and why it‚Äôs bad:  https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1138581732637237250?s=21¬†‚Ä¶ https://twitter.com/kyledcheney/status/1138542639903649792¬†‚Ä¶

House rules aren‚Äôt clear on whether a vote of the House is required to authorize these lawsuits, but that‚Äôs been our practice. #HRes430 instead says that a vote of House leadership to authorize these lawsuits ‚Äúis the equivalent of a vote of the full House of Representatives.‚Äù

#HRes430 isn‚Äôt a contempt resolution; it authorizes Rep. Nadler to file lawsuits to enforce specific subpoenas but, unfortunately, shifts to leadership the power to authorize future enforcement lawsuits, further centralizing the House‚Äôs authority and undermining the institution.

‚Äú‚Ä¶he shall take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄîConstitution, Art. II, ¬ß3

Five threads on Mueller‚Äôs report & Pres. Trump‚Äôs impeachable conduct:

The president and his allies are instead trying to excuse Trump‚Äôs efforts to obstruct the entire investigation into Russian election interference by alleging problems with elements of it and claiming, without basis, that they undermine Mueller‚Äôs obstruction analysis.
And with Mueller‚Äôs report now out, the White House no longer has anything positive to say about Mueller and his team.
But, as we later found out, Mueller‚Äôs report is damning for the president. If Barr‚Äôs letter had accurately reflected the report, the White House would not have reacted positively.

When Barr‚Äôs letter came out, the White House abruptly changed its tone. Trump said ‚Äúthe Mueller report was great‚Äù and that Mueller had acted honorably, and he touted the report as a ‚Äútotal exoneration.‚Äù Kellyanne Conway referred to the investigation as ‚Äúthe gold standard.‚Äù

The White House‚Äôs reaction to Barr‚Äôs letter is also telling. Trump had long been harshly critical of Mueller and his investigation, calling him ‚Äútotally conflicted‚Äù and ‚Äúdisgraced and discredited,‚Äù and the investigation ‚Äúillegal‚Äù and a ‚Äúrigged witch hunt.‚Äù

Mueller wrote that it would be improper for him to conclude that Trump should be charged, given that he could not actually charge him, because it would put a criminal accusation over the president‚Äôs head, with no opportunity for a formal defense.

It‚Äôs not that Mueller couldn‚Äôt make up his mind, chose not to make a decision, and then said Trump wasn‚Äôt exonerated; rather, Mueller had decided that it was inappropriate to make a determination as to whether Trump had committed a crime, and he sought to make that fact clearer.
But in context‚Äîwhich Barr fails to provide‚ÄîMueller‚Äôs declaration makes more sense.
Here‚Äôs the tweet expressing my displeasure: https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1110931164909449218¬†‚Ä¶

Because it was unclear why Mueller chose not to decide whether to charge the president with a crime, I was unhappy about this line from Mueller, quoted by Barr: ‚Äúwhile this report does not conclude that the President committed a crime, it also does not exonerate him.‚Äù

Barr doesn‚Äôt even mention that, because of the DoJ opinion, Mueller believed that charging a sitting president with a crime was not an option; Barr only cites the DoJ opinion in a footnote when describing his own analysis, not Mueller‚Äôs analysis.

Note that my March 24 tweet doesn‚Äôt even mention obstruction. That‚Äôs because Barr‚Äôs letter falsely implies Mueller looked at the evidence and simply could not decide whether Trump should be indicted because of legal and factual issues regarding whether his actions were criminal.

Mueller explains that prudential concerns and an official DoJ opinion prevented him from indicting the president, and then, because it would be unfair to accuse the president of a crime without actually charging him, Mueller declined to decide whether Trump had committed a crime.

Mueller‚Äôs report describes acts of obstruction by President Trump, and it clearly says Mueller chose not to decide whether Trump had committed a crime because Mueller was prohibited from actually charging him.

As you can see from the attached tweet, I initially fell for Attorney General Barr‚Äôs March 24 letter of principal conclusions‚Äîbut then I read Mueller‚Äôs report. https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1109933533416427520¬†‚Ä¶
